itemDescription: Anglo-Irish author, barrister, medical doctor, officer in the Royal Army Medical Corps and historian

wikipedia_page.main: Major-General  Robert James Blackham  (1868–1951) was an author, barrister, medical doctor and officer in the Royal Army Medical Corps.

response: * January 23 – Robert J. Blackham, British general and author (b. 1868)

Harold Saunders Blackham was born in London, England; his father William George Blackham was an Ulster Protestant from Newry, while his mother was an Englishwoman named Evison Elizabeth Saunders. An uncle of his was Robert J. Blackham who was the Surgeon General to the British Army in Ireland. The Blackham family were evangelical Protestants, against which Hugh rebelled when he converted to the Catholic Church, in accordance with the  decree of 1907, to enable him to marry Mary McCarville of County Monaghan (with whom he had two sons Eoin and Carol).
* Robert J. Blackham (1868–1951), author, doctor and army officer
* Robert J. Blackham (16 September 1868 – 23 January 1951), author of Apron Men; The Romance of Freemasonry

In the First World War he was initially based in Bombay, on training duties, then served with the Sanitary Division of the ADMS in Mesopotamia and was Mentioned in Dispatches. He was the joint creator, with Robert J. Blackham, of the "Harvey-Blackham" pattern used on St John’s Ambulances in the Far East.

In 1932 Blackham's cousin Aodh de Blácam published a collection of his poems called 'Bard of Clanrye' (Talbot press, Dublin 1932), this publication was financed by another of Blackham's cousins Robert J. Blackham. One poem featured in 'Bard of Clanrye' called 'Homeland' expresses Blackham's feelings of being so far away from the land he grew up in.
